Award.AwardTitle: Pattern Selection: Growth, Fronts, and Defects
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project aims to mathematically describe physical and biological growth processes through direct modeling and analysis of coherent structures. Particular model examples create regular patterns such as stripes or hexagonal lattices of spots. The goal of this research is to find mathematical characterizations of patterns that explain the ubiquity of such regular patterns across nature and, at the same time, to provide recipes for the self-organized manufacturing of microstructure. The project includes research activities that will train graduate and undergraduate students.

The project focuses on perturbation methods that are applicable to systems without a technically viable spatial dynamics interpretation, including nonlocal and multi-dimensional problems. It will explore the interaction of the domain growth and pattern-formation and mechanisms of the speed-selection for traveling fronts. In particular, the research aims to develop techniques for the study of perturbation and bifurcation problems in infinite dimensional dynamical systems in the presence of essential spectrum using rigorous core/far-field decompositions. Beyond local perturbation analysis, these strategies will be implemented in numerical continuation algorithms, with a priori and a posteriori error bounds. Particular goals set forth are wavenumber and pattern predictions in growing domains, characterization of invasion speeds in pattern-forming systems, and depinning asymptotics in heterogeneous media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many spatially extended complex systems display a surprising degree of spatio-temporal order, with examples ranging  from vegetation patterns in arid and semi-arid environments over ripples in thin films and eutectic crystal growth to collective motion in bacterial colonies and patterning in early embryonal development. However, models of such systems often exhibit complex dynamics with little to no observable coherence at macroscopic scales, when simulated with spatially random, incoherent initial conditions. Quite different phenomena emerge when these systems are observed in growing domains, either engineered through directional quenching, or arising through self-organized growth in an invasion process. Such growth processes lead to selection of wavelength and macroscopic alignment of patterns. The results of this project give quantitative predictions for the patterns observed in such growth processes based on both asymptotic analysis and novel computational techniques. They predict the orientation of stripes and ripples relative to growth directions, dominant wavelengths of patterns, and the emergence of defects. 
The results can guide the design of controlled experiments that exploit the self-assembly properties of materials, but they also allow us to infer the history of growth processes from the resulting observable pattern. The project provided training opportunities for 8 undergraduate in summer research projects and for 3 graduate students supporting the preparation of their thesis and mentoring opportunities with undergraduate students. Results from student projects have been published in premier journals and presented at international conferences.
